page.title: 10HISTORIC BUILDINGS KNUTSFORD
page.content: Knutsford's oldest buildings date from 1688. The Chapel was built for dissenters who were allowed to carry on their worship by the Toleration Act of 1672. Along King Street there are 17th century cottages near the site of the old Town Stocks. At the corner of Stanley Road and Toft Road is a nineteenth century house which was the residence of the prison governor. It is now the Town's tourist office. La Belle Epoque restaurant is a nineteenth century building designed by Richard Harding Watt who was fascinated by Italian and Moorish (North African) architecture and Knutsford is famous for his work. His designs can be seen on the memorial tower to Mrs. Gaskell and the houses in Legh Road, Drury Lane and Moorside.
